subtopics.summary: Introduction to the Second Law, focusing on the **Kelvin-Planck Statement**: 'It is impossible for any device that operates on a cycle to receive heat from a single reservoir and produce a net amount of work.' This describes the impossibility of a Perpetual Motion Machine of the Second Kind (PMM2).

Introduction of the **Clausius Statement**: 'It is impossible to construct a device that operates in a cycle and produces no effect other than the transfer of heat from a lower-temperature body to a higher-temperature body.' This defines the required input work for refrigerators and heat pumps.

Demonstration that the Kelvin-Planck and Clausius statements are equivalent; violating one automatically violates the other. The two statements are used interchangeably as the foundation for the Second Law of Thermodynamics.

Definition of a **Reversible Process** (one that can be reversed without leaving a trace on the surroundings) and identification of common causes of **Irreversibilities** (e.g., friction, unrestrained expansion, heat transfer through a finite temperature difference).

subtopics.topic: The Carnot Cycle and Thermal Efficiency
subtopics.summary: Introduction to the **Carnot Cycle**, the most efficient reversible cycle. Definition of **Thermal Efficiency** ($$\eta_{\text{th}}$$) as the ratio of net work output to heat input: $$\eta_{\text{th}} = \\frac{W_{\text{net,out}}}{Q_H} = 1 - \\frac{Q_L}{Q_H}$$

Summary of the **Carnot Principles** (all reversible engines operating between the same two reservoirs have the same efficiency). Derivation of the **Thermodynamic Temperature Scale**: $$\frac{Q_H}{Q_L} = \frac{T_H}{T_L}$$

Definition of the **Coefficient of Performance (COP)** for heat pumps (reverse Carnot cycle) as a measure of performance: $$COP_{\text{HP}} = \\frac{Q_H}{W_{\text{net,in}}}$$ and the relationship to reversible efficiency: $$COP_{\text{HP,rev}} = \\frac{1}{\\eta_{\text{th,rev}}}$$

An in-class challenge problem to apply Carnot concepts: analyzing the state and work output when a reversible isothermal compression step in the cycle is replaced by an irreversible adiabatic compression.
